data.name: Guess a secret prime number through the yield/send mechanism
data.description:
An ape named Gimmy has a prime number in his mind. He challenges you to guess what it is. He will call your `guess_my_prime_number()` repeatedly until you guess it right. The repeated guesses should be returned using `yield`. If you guessed wrong, a clue will be sent to you using `send()`. The clue `too big` means your guess was too big; `too small` means it's too small. Here's the code that the Ape will use to send the clue to you:
```
# The Ape's code
gen = guess_my_prime_number()
guess = next(gen)
while guess != secret_prime :
    if not is_prime(guess):
        guess = gen.send("prime!")   # send no clue if the guess was not a prime number
    elif guess < p:
        guess = gen.send("too big")  
    else:
        guess = gen.send("too small")
```
In response to the clue that you recieve using `yield`, you can change your guess accordingly using code like this:
```
# Your code
clue = yield my_guess
if clue == "too small" :
    my_guess += 1   # If the previous guess was too small, now I need to guess a larger number
elif clue == "too big":
    my_guess -= 1
elif clue == "prime!":
    do_something  # The previous guess was not a prime number and the ape didn't offer a clue.
```

Ape Gimmy knows only prime numbers. If your guess is not a prime number, he will have no clue and send you `prime!`.

Ape Gimmy blinks from time to time. Whenever he blinks, he comes up with a different prime number in his mind. When that happens, he will send you a clue "blink!". 

If you guessed it right, a new round will start, again with a fresh call to your `guess_my_prime_number()`. 

Ape Gimmy has a big brain and prime numbers in his mind can be almost as large as 2<sup>100</sup>.
